factoid: Prince Andrew felt a pang.
Prince Andrew did not know why he felt a pang.
The day was beautiful.
The sun was bright.
Everything around was gay.
The slim pretty girl did not know of Prince Andrew's existence.
The slim pretty girl was contented and cheerful in her own separate life.
The slim pretty girl was probably foolish but bright and happy.
Prince Andrew wondered what the slim pretty girl was glad about.
Prince Andrew wondered what the slim pretty girl was thinking.
Prince Andrew's thoughts were not about military regulations or arrangement of Ryazan serfs' quitrents.
In 1809 Count Ilya Rostov was living at Otradnoe.
Count Ilya Rostov entertained the province with hunts, theatricals, dinners, and music.
Count Ilya Rostov was glad to see Prince Andrew.
Count Ilya Rostov insisted Prince Andrew stay the night.
During the day Prince Andrew was entertained by his elderly hosts and important visitors.
The old count's house was crowded due to an approaching name day.
Prince Andrew repeatedly glanced at Natasha.
Natasha was gay and laughing among younger members of the company.
Prince Andrew wondered what Natasha was thinking about.
Prince Andrew wondered why Natasha was glad.
That night Prince Andrew could not sleep.
Prince Andrew read for a while.
Prince Andrew put out his candle.
Prince Andrew relit the candle.
The room was hot.
The room's shutters were closed.
Prince Andrew was cross with Count Ilya Rostov.
Count Ilya Rostov had made Prince Andrew stay.
Count Ilya Rostov assured Prince Andrew that necessary documents had not yet arrived from town.
Prince Andrew was vexed with himself for having stayed.
Prince Andrew opened the window shutters.
Moonlight burst into the room.
Prince Andrew opened the casement.
The night was fresh, bright, and very still.
A row of pollard trees was outside the window.
The trees were black on one side and had silvery light on the other.
Beneath the trees grew lush wet bushy vegetation with silver-lit leaves and stems.
A roof glittered with dew beyond the dark trees.
A leafy tree with a brilliantly white trunk and branches was to the right.
The moon was nearly full in a pale, almost starless spring sky.
Prince Andrew leaned his elbows on the window ledge.
Prince Andrew rested his eyes on the sky.
Prince Andrew's room was on the first floor.
Rooms above Prince Andrew's were also awake.
Prince Andrew heard female voices overhead.
A girlish voice above Prince Andrew said "Just once more."
Another voice asked "When are you coming to bed?"
The first voice replied "I won't, I can't sleep, what's the use? Come now for the last time."
Two girlish voices sang a musical passage.
A voice said "Oh, how lovely! Now go to sleep, and there's an end of it."
A voice said "You go to sleep, but I can't."
The voice was leaning right out of the window.
The voice's dress rustled and breathing could be heard.
Everything was stone-still.
Prince Andrew dared not stir for fear of betraying his presence.
Prince Andrew heard "Sonia! Sonia!" from above.
A voice said "Oh, how can you sleep? Only look how glorious it is!"
A voice said "Ah, how glorious! Do wake up, Sonia!" with tears.
A voice said "There never, never was such a lovely night before!"
Sonia made a reluctant reply.
A voice said "Do just come and see what a moon! Oh, how lovely! Come here... Darling sweetheart, come here!"
A voice said she felt like sitting down on her heels, putting arms round her knees, and flying away.
A voice warned "Take care, you'll fall out."
Prince Andrew heard a scuffle.
Sonia's disapproving voice said "It's past one o'clock."
Sonia said "Oh, you only spoil things for me. All right, go, go!"
All was silent, but Prince Andrew knew Sonia was still sitting there.
From time to time Prince Andrew heard a soft rustle.
From time to time Prince Andrew heard a sigh.
